channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Large Explosion Hits Cairo Police Headquarters
item.description: A car bomb struck the Egyptian police headquarters in downtown Cairo on Friday, killing at least three people and wounding dozens, the country's state media reported.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: U.N. Says Muslims Were Massacred in Tense Myanmar Region
item.description: Human rights groups say that with this latest round of anti-Muslim violence, Myanmar’s government appears to be trying to cover up the problem.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY

item.title: India Ink: Raid in Delhi Neighborhood Rattles African Residents
item.description: Finding themselves under increased scrutiny, many residents of Khirki Extension were fearful about talking about the way they have been treated during their stay in India.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Number of Darfur’s Displaced Surged in 2013
item.description: A report by the top United Nations peacekeeping official to the Security Council presented a pessimistic picture of the decade-old Darfur conflict.
item.category: United Nations Department of Peacekeeping Operations
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Claims of Police Brutality in Ukraine Amid Talks to Quell Unrest
item.description: As negotiations went on between opposition leaders and the president of Ukraine, a video surfaced of Berkut riot police officers stripping a protester naked.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
item.media:description: Protesters clashed with police on Thursday in central Kiev.

item.title: World Briefing: Deadly Fire at a Nursing Home in Canada
item.description: The fire in Quebec killed at least five people and left 30 missing, all of them believed to be 80 or older and many with limited mobility.
item.dc:creator: By IAN AUSTEN

item.title: World Briefing: Al Qaeda Calls for Rebel Unity in Syria
item.description: In an audio recording released Thursday, the leader of Al Qaeda called on Islamist brigades in northern Syria to stop fighting one another.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By BEN HUBBARD

item.title: Japan’s Leader Compares Strain With China to Germany and Britain in 1914
item.description: The blunt remarks, which concurred with others made recently by prominent historians, provoked an angry response from Beijing.
item.dc:creator: By JANE PERLEZ

item.title: U.S. Willing to Hold Talks if Snowden Pleads Guilty
item.description: Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. did not specify the guilty pleas the Justice Department would expect before it would open talks with Mr. Snowden’s lawyers.
item.dc:creator: By STEVE KENNY

item.title: The Lede: Scarlett Johansson’s SodaStream Endorsement Deal Conflicts With Charity Work, Aid Group Says
item.description: Oxfam has distanced itself from one of its global ambassadors, Scarlett Johansson, since she agreed to become the face of SodaStream, an Israeli firm that makes products in a settlement in the occupied West Bank.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: U.S. Warns Against Business With Iran
item.description: The warning came as the Treasury announced a settlement with a European bank for having allowed Iran to bypass sanctions by using the company’s access to American banks.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: After Shaky Beginning, Sides Report Progress at Syria Peace Talks
item.description: A mediator was laying the ground for face-to-face talks, reflecting the daunting challenges of seeking a political resolution to the conflict.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Lakhdar Brahimi, the international mediator in the Syrian peace talks, with United Nations Secretary General Ban Ki-moon on Wednesday in Montreux.

item.title: Relaying Of Scores Is at Center Of Case
item.description: The arrest of a British man represents a rare attempt to prosecute a person for relaying information from a live sports event.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN MARTIN

item.title: Industry Awakens to Threat of Climate Change
item.description: Coca-Cola and other corporations are starting to see global warming as an economically disruptive force affecting commodity costs and supply chains.
item.dc:creator: By CORAL DAVENPORT
item.media:credit: Andrew Link/Winona Daily News, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A Coke bottling plant in Winona, Minn. The company has been affected by global droughts.

item.title: U.S. and Iran Offer Clashing Accounts of the Civil War in Syria
item.description: The contrasting descriptions illustrated the chasm that still separates the United States and Iran on Middle East issues even as they have agreed on a temporary nuclear accord.
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD and MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: At a forum in Switzerland, President Hassan Rouhani of Iran on Thursday referred to rebels in Syria as “ruthless killers.”

item.title: Cuban Vendors, in Rare Move, Stage a Protest
item.description: In a rare demonstration of dissent, dozens of Cuban artisans and vendors protested government inspectors in the city of Holguín, witnesses said.
item.dc:creator: By DAMIEN CAVE

item.title: Imider Journal: On Moroccan Hill, Villagers Make Stand Against a Mine
item.description: An unlikely spot for a settlement was established to protest a mining company’s expropriation of precious water supplies, as well as the pollution that results from the mining.
item.dc:creator: By AIDA ALAMI
item.media:credit: Leila Alaoui for The New York Times
item.media:description: An activist with the Berber flag. Protesters have occupied a hilltop above a silver mine for more than two years.

item.title: Pentagon Study Finds Agencies Ill Equipped to Detect Foreign Nuclear Efforts
item.description: A report by the Defense Science Board suggests using some of the techniques that the National Security Agency has employed against terrorists.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID E. SANGER and WILLIAM J. BROAD

item.title: Lens Blog: Where the Ice, and the Population, Is Thinning
item.description: The Slovenian photographer Ciril Jazbec, awed by the subsistence hunters of remote northern Greenland, trekked there to document their lives even though he knows only one word in Greenlandic.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW BORYGA
item.media:description: The remote settlement that the photographer Ciril Jazbec visited has a population of only 250 people.

item.title: South Sudan Cease-Fire Signed After More Than a Month of Fighting
item.description: An agreement between the government and rebels loyal to the ousted vice president raised hopes of peace after more than a month of fighting.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By NICHOLAS KULISH and BENNO MUCHLER

item.title: The Lede: Video From NASA on 10th Anniversary of Mars Rover Program
item.description: On the 10th anniversary of the landing of the rover Opportunity, a look at what has been learned from its Martian adventures.
item.dc:creator: By JENNIFER PRESTON

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Shanghai Test Scores and the Mystery of the Missing Children
item.description: China’s restrictions on internal migration serve to drive migrant children out of the city as early as primary school, statistics show, and critics say that skews testing results indicating its education system’s equity and superiority.
item.category: Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development
item.dc:creator: By HELEN GAO
item.media:credit: Ariana Lindquist for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pupils line up at a Shanghai school for children of migrant workers. Some have questioned whether migrants are fairly represented in Shanghai test results.

item.title: Argentina’s Currency Falls Sharply Against the Dollar, Stirring Inflation Fears
item.description: The peso lost 8 percent of its value relative to the American dollar in one day, the worst performance since Argentina’s 2002 financial crisis.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Li’s New Role in a Grand Slam Final: Favorite
item.description: Li’s coach, Carlos Rodriguez, is eager to see how his player deals psychologically with being expected to beat Dominika Cibulkova on Saturday in the Australian Open women’s final.
item.dc:creator: By BEN ROTHENBERG
item.media:description: Li Na at a practice session with her coach, Carlos Rodriguez, in Melbourne.

item.title: U.S. Offshore Wind Farm, Made in Europe
item.description: The promise of new jobs and work failed to come true, revealing shortcomings in the American offshore wind industry.
item.dc:creator: By DIANE CARDWELL
item.media:credit: Gretchen Ertl for The New York Times
item.media:description: Joel Gonzalez at Mass Tank in Middleborough, Mass. Mass Tank failed to gain work on a wind farm off Cape Cod.
